title: Analysis in government
body: Good quality evidence is key to making better decisions. Departments across government collect and analyse data for a wide variety of outputs. These outputs include official statistics, operational reports and predictive models for policy making.

title: New Article Title
body:
The RAP process is based on several core principles. These principals combine to:

  • Increase quality
  • Enhance trust
  • Boost efficiency
  • Better business continuity and knowledge management

title: New Article Title
body: None of the challenges and aims we have been discussing are new. When it comes to implementing our principles, there is a lot we can learn and borrow from the world of software engineering.

title: What is the problem with this way of working?
displayTitle: What is the problem with this way of working?
body:
Pipelines often contain manual steps, for example copy-pasting or manually moving data. Each manual step is an opportunity to make a mistake. The more times the analysis is repeated, the greater the chance of an error.

It is difficult to document manual steps in a pipeline. Where documentation does not exist, knowledge becomes siloed in individual analysts. Where it does exists, it often forms lengthy desk instructions. This documentation focuses on practical information rather than the analytical decisions made. It can get separated from the analysis and become outdated. Often neither the documentation nor the raw analysis is shared with the public or external experts.

title: Modular code
body:
When creating Reproducible Analytical Pipelines, it is important that we not only code, but code well. One important part of writing code well is making it modular. This means breaking your code down into self-contained elements, for example modules, classes, and functions. Functions are the lowest level of our code. They should do one thing and do it well. Modules are collections of related functions. We can run our pipeline from a high level script that calls in functions from our modules. Classes are features of some programming languages, for example python, that can help us structure our code. Modularising code makes it more readable, and easier to update or fix. If one part breaks or needs updating, only that part has to change.

Once we have modularised our code, we can go one step further and package it. A package is a self-contained collection of code, documentation, and example data, that can be imported and run. Two examples of packages written by analysts in government are gptables and fingertipsR.

title: Module references and further resources
body:
Recommended resources:

  • Reproducible Analytical Pipelines: Overcoming barriers to adoption - review into the adoption of RAP from the Office for Statistics Regulation
  • User Engagement Top Tips - guidance on user engagement, from the Analysis Function
  • Agile Essentials - introduction to Agile from the Agile Alliance
  • Scrum Guide - official guide to Scrum from the creators of the Scrum framework
  • Agile Coach - guide to Agile development from Atlassian, creator of software to aid Agile development
  • Agile delivery - guidance on Agile in the public sector, from the Government Digital Service 

Additional references:

  • Project management timeline: ordering all phases - blog on Waterfall project management, from ILX Group, provider of PRINCE2 training

title: Bringing it together
body: Bringing all these elements together is what gives us a Reproducible Analytical Pipeline. There is a direct line from importing the data, processing, analysing, right through to dissemination. Our functions are kept all together in a well-tested reusable package. We can import this package into a single script that will run our analysis and return our final output. Alongside this output, we can produce an automated quality assurance report or log, to flag any issues with the process.

title: Proportionality
body:
Implementing even one of the RAP techniques will improve the trustworthiness and quality of our analysis. However, the RAP champions network defines the RAP Minimum Viable Product (MVP) as follows.

At a minimum, a RAP must:

  • Minimise manual steps, for example copy-paste, point-click or drag-drop operations. Where it is absolutely necessary to include a manual step in the process this must be documented as described below.
  • Be built using open source software which is available to anyone, preferably R or python.
  • Deepen technical and quality assurance processes with peer review to ensure that the process is reproducible and that the below requirements have been met.
  • Guarantee an audit trail using version control software, preferably Git.
  • Be open to anyone – this can be facilitated most easily through the use of file and code sharing platforms.
  • Follow existing good practice for quality assurance – guidance set by departments or organisations, and by the Analysis Function teams and Data Quality Hub for the Analysis Function and Government Statistical Service.
  • Contain well-commented code and have documentation embedded and version controlled within the product, rather than saved elsewhere.

title: Module references and further resources
body:
Recommended resources:

  • Duck Book - Analysis Function guidance on the quality assurance of code for analysis and research
  • RAP Minimum Viable Product - guidance developed by the RAP Champions network
  • GDS Service Standard - standards for teams creating or running public services, from the Government Digital Service
  • govcookiecutter - template for data science projects within the public sector
  • gptables package - package for writing consistently formatted statistical tables to Excel
  • Reproducible Reporting with RMarkdown - introductory course on using R Markdown to produce reproducible reports
  • R Packages - open book by Hadley Wickham and Jenny Bryan
  • The nature of Reproducible Analytical Pipelines (RAP) - blog about the Nature of Crime RAP project
  • ONS Centre for Crime and Justice GitHub - GitHub repositories for the Nature of Crime RAP project
  • fingertipsR - open R package to interact with Public Health England’s Fingertips data tool
  • cis_households - open python package for processing the household COVID-19 Infection Survey (CIS)
